aws::graph::propositions: # Witness Information from Pilot of N911FA
Pilot N911FA began her day at 0530.
Pilot N911FA checked weather throughout the day.
Pilot N911FA noted precipitation/rain during the day.
Pilot N911FA's first two flights of the day were for traffic evaluation.
Pilot N911FA encountered no problems during the first two flights.
Pilot N911FA reported marginal weather conditions.
Pilot N911FA made the decision to fly after conferring with her lieutenant.
Pilot N911FA agreed with her lieutenant that she would return to base if the weather was not good.
Pilot N911FA and two passengers departed about 1552.
Pilot N911FA reported they were airborne for only a few minutes before returning to the heliport.
Pilot N911FA returned to the heliport due to weather.
Pilot N911FA broadcasted her position per protocol while returning to the heliport.
Pilot N911FA performed a reconnaissance of the area upon arrival at the heliport.
Pilot N911FA checked to make sure there were no people in the area.
Pilot N911FA saw the outline of helicopter N96BM on landing pad 1.
Pilot N911FA was not sure if the main rotor blades of N96BM were turning or not.
Pilot N911FA continued the approach to the heliport.
Pilot N911FA radioed her intention and location.
Pilot N911FA received no response from anyone after radioing her intention and location.
Pilot N911FA heard a helicopter radio querying "any Pasadena on 02?" on short final.
Pilot N911FA responded to the radio query.
Pilot N911FA did not hear the response as her helicopter had gone below the mountains.
Pilot N911FA observed N96BM on the ground on final approach.
Pilot N911FA assumed N96BM was on pad 1.
Pilot N911FA had no direct/established communications with the pilot of N96BM.
Pilot N911FA hover-taxied to Pad 2.
Pilot N911FA was concentrating on keeping her helicopter in the box for Pad 2.
Pilot N911FA was getting on the radios to tell the passengers to stay put.
Pilot N911FA simultaneously lowered pitch while communicating with passengers.
Pilot N911FA stated that the "sky fell" at that point.
Pilot N911FA had seen two helmets in helicopter N96BM.
Pilot N911FA did not have eye contact with the pilot of N96BM.
Pilot N911FA did not have eye contact with the Tactical Flight Officer (TFO) of N96BM.
The windscreen of N911FA was wet with water drops.
The side windows of N911FA were wet with water drops.
Pilot N911FA was looking forward to stay straight during landing.
Pilot N911FA was utilizing the chin window during landing.
Pilot N911FA was utilizing her periphery to land inside the box.
Pilot N911FA did not realize at the time that helicopter N96BM was not in the box.

text:
# WITNESS INFORMATION

## Pilot N911FA

According to the pilot of N911FA, her day began at 0530. Throughout the day, she checked weather and noted precipitation/rain during the day. The first two flights of the day were for traffic evaluation with no problems encountered. The pilot reported marginal weather conditions, but made the decision to fly after conferring with her lieutenant that if the weather was not good, she would return to base. The pilot and two passengers departed about 1552; the pilot reported that they were airborne for only a few minutes before returning to the heliport to land due to weather.

While on the return back to the heliport, the pilot had broadcasted her position per protocol. Upon arrival at the heliport, the pilot performed a reconnaissance of the area to make sure there were no people in the area. When she looked at the landing pads, she saw the outline of N96BM on landing pad 1; the pilot was not sure if the main rotor blades were turning or not. The pilot continued the approach, and radioed her intention and location, but received no response from anyone. On short final, she heard a helicopter radio querying if there was "any Pasadena on 02?" She responded, but did not hear the response as her helicopter had gone below the mountains.

On final she observed N96BM on the ground and assumed it to be on pad 1; at the time there was no direct/established communications with the pilot of N96BM. The pilot hover-taxied to Pad 2, and was concentrating on keeping her helicopter in the box for Pad 2. She stated that she was getting on the radios to tell the passengers to stay put, and simultaneously lowered pitch; at that point the, "sky fell." The pilot stated that she had seen two helmets in the helicopter, but did not have eye contact with the pilot or TFO of the other helicopter.

The pilot stated that the windscreen and side windows were wet with water drops. She was looking forward to stay straight and utilizing the chin window and her periphery to land inside the box.

The pilot stated that at the time she did not realize that the parked helicopter (N96BM) was not in the box.
